getting-started-intro: Welcome to AI PBX! This platform allows you to create intelligent voice assistants powered by large language models and integrate them into your business phone system or website.
getting-started-what-is-content: AI PBX is a cloud-based platform that combines artificial intelligence with traditional telephony. It enables businesses to automate customer interactions through natural language conversations, replacing or augmenting traditional call centers.
getting-started-feature-1: AI-powered voice conversations with natural language understanding
getting-started-feature-2: Integration with CRM, ERP, and other business systems via function calling
getting-started-feature-3: Multi-channel support: voice calls, WhatsApp, Telegram, web chat
getting-started-feature-5: SIP trunk integration for existing phone systems
getting-started-feature-6: WebRTC integration for website voice calls
getting-started-step-1: Log in to your AI PBX account
getting-started-step-3: Click 'Create Assistant' and configure your first voice assistant
getting-started-step-4: Test your assistant in the Playground
getting-started-step-5: Publish your assistant via SIP or WebRTC
dashboard-overview-intro: The Dashboard provides a comprehensive overview of your AI PBX system, showing key metrics and quick access to important features.
dashboard-overview-metric-1: Total Calls - Number of calls handled by your assistants
dashboard-overview-metric-2: Total Duration - Cumulative call time across all assistants
dashboard-overview-metric-3: Total Tokens - AI tokens consumed during conversations
dashboard-overview-metric-4: Total Cost - Total expenses for the selected period
dashboard-screenshot-caption: Dashboard showing system metrics and statistics
dashboard-metrics-intro: Understanding the metrics on your dashboard helps you monitor system performance and costs.
dashboard-metrics-calls-content: Shows the total number of calls handled by your voice assistants during the selected time period.
dashboard-metrics-duration-content: Displays the cumulative duration of all calls, helping you understand usage patterns.
dashboard-metrics-tokens-content: Tracks the number of AI tokens consumed. Tokens are used for both speech recognition and language model processing.
dashboard-metrics-cost-content: Shows total expenses based on token usage and call duration.
dashboard-navigation-intro: From the dashboard, you can quickly navigate to all major sections:
dashboard-navigation-item-4: Reports - View detailed analytics and call history
assistants-create-intro: Creating your first voice assistant is straightforward. Follow these steps to get started.
assistants-create-step-1: Click the 'Add Assistant' button on the Assistants page
assistants-create-step-2: Enter a name for your assistant (e.g., 'Customer Support Bot')
assistants-create-step-3: Select an AI model (we recommend starting with GPT)
assistants-create-step-4: Choose a voice from the available options
assistants-create-step-5: Write a welcome phrase that the assistant will say when a call starts
assistant-create-screenshot-caption: Assistant creation dialog showing configuration options
assistants-create-note: You can always edit these settings later. Start simple and refine as you test.
assistants-config-intro: The assistant configuration is organized into four main tabs, each controlling different aspects of your voice assistant.
assistants-config-main-content: The Main tab contains essential settings:
assistants-config-main-name: Assistant Name - A descriptive name for internal use
assistants-config-main-model: Model - The AI language model to use (GPT, Qwen, etc.)
assistants-config-main-voice: Voice - The voice persona for text-to-speech
assistants-config-main-comment: Comment - Optional notes about this assistant
assistants-config-prompts-welcome: Welcome Phrase - The first thing customers hear when calling
assistants-config-prompts-system: System Prompt - Instructions that guide the assistant's behavior and knowledge
assistants-config-parameters-content: Advanced settings for speech recognition, synthesis, VAD (Voice Activity Detection), and audio formats.
assistants-config-publication-content: Options for deploying your assistant via SIP trunk, WebRTC, or call forwarding.
assistants-models-intro: AI PBX supports multiple language models. Choosing the right model depends on your use case and budget.
assistants-models-available-content: The platform supports GPT, Qwen, and other models. Each has different capabilities, speed, and cost characteristics.
assistants-models-choose-1: GPT: Best for complex conversations requiring deep understanding
assistants-models-choose-2: Qwen: Faster and more cost-effective for simpler tasks
assistants-models-choose-3: Consider your budget, response time requirements, and conversation complexity
assistants-voices-intro: Voice selection determines how your assistant sounds to callers. Choose a voice that matches your brand and audience.
assistants-voices-selection-content: We offer a variety of voices with different accents, genders, and tones. Test different voices in the Playground to find the best fit.
assistants-voices-languages-content: Voices are available for multiple languages including English, Russian, German, Chinese, and more.
assistants-speech-intro: Speech settings control how your assistant recognizes and generates speech.
assistants-speech-recognition-content: Configure how incoming audio is processed:
assistants-speech-recognition-language: Language - The expected language of incoming speech
assistants-speech-synthesis-content: Text-to-Speech settings determine how the assistant's responses are converted to audio.
assistants-speech-vad-content: VAD detects when the caller starts and stops speaking:
assistants-speech-vad-threshold: Threshold - Minimum duration to detect speech (in milliseconds)
assistants-speech-vad-silence: Silence Duration - How long to wait after speech stops before processing
assistants-speech-vad-included: Included Audio Duration - Amount of audio before VAD trigger to include
assistants-speech-vad-semantic: Semantic VAD - Advanced detection using AI understanding (Auto, Low, Medium, High)
assistants-speech-audio-content: Configure input and output audio formats based on your integration method (typically handled automatically).
assistants-publish-intro: Once your assistant is configured and tested, you can publish it for production use through several methods.
assistants-publish-sip-content: Connect your assistant to an existing phone system:
assistants-publish-sip-step-1: Go to the Publication tab in your assistant settings
assistants-publish-sip-step-4: Copy the generated SIP URI and configure it in your phone system
assistants-publish-webrtc-content: Embed a voice call widget on your website to allow visitors to speak with your assistant directly from their browser.
assistants-publish-webrtc-note: WebRTC scripts are generated per assistant and can be customized with your branding.
assistants-publish-forwarding-content: Forward calls from an external phone number to your assistant.
tools-understanding-intro: Tools (also called Function Calling) enable your voice assistant to perform actions and access external data during conversations.
tools-understanding-what-content: Tools are functions that the AI can call during a conversation to retrieve information or perform actions. For example, checking appointment availability, creating orders, or looking up customer information.
tools-understanding-use-case-1: Booking appointments by checking calendar availability
tools-understanding-use-case-2: Looking up order status in your CRM
tools-create-intro: AI PBX supports three types of tools, each suited for different integration scenarios.
tools-create-function-content: Direct function calling where the AI provides structured data that your system processes.
tools-create-webhook-content: HTTP-based integration where the assistant makes API calls to your endpoints.
tools-create-mcp-content: Model Context Protocol for more complex integrations with external services.
tools-create-step-1: Go to the Tools page and click 'Create Tool'
tools-create-step-2: Enter a name and description (the description helps the AI understand when to use this tool)
tools-create-step-3: Select the tool type (Webhook for most integrations)
tools-create-step-4: Configure parameters that the AI should collect before calling the tool
tools-create-step-5: Save the tool and assign it to your assistants
tool-create-screenshot-caption: Tool creation interface showing parameter configuration
tools-config-intro: Proper tool configuration ensures the AI knows when and how to use each tool effectively.
tools-config-basic-name: Name - Internal identifier for the tool
tools-config-basic-description: Description - Detailed explanation that helps the AI understand when to use this tool
tools-config-parameters-content: Define what information the AI should collect before calling the tool:
tools-config-parameters-step-3: Add a description explaining what this parameter is for
tools-config-parameters-step-4: Mark as required if the tool cannot work without this parameter
tools-config-note: Write clear, detailed descriptions. The AI uses these to understand when to ask the caller for specific information.
tools-auth-intro: For webhook-based tools, you can configure authentication to secure your API endpoints.
tools-auth-none-content: Use for public endpoints or when authentication is handled through other means.
tools-auth-bearer-content: Sends an Authorization header with a bearer token. Enter your API token in the configuration.
tools-auth-basic-content: Traditional username/password authentication. Provide login credentials that will be sent with each request.
tools-mcp-intro: MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers provide a standardized way to connect AI assistants to external tools and data sources.
tools-mcp-config-content: When creating an MCP tool, configure:
tools-mcp-config-url: Server URL - The endpoint of your MCP server
tools-mcp-config-headers: Custom Headers - Additional HTTP headers (JSON format)
playground-testing-intro: The Playground provides a safe environment to test your assistants before deploying them to production.
playground-testing-step-2: Select the assistant you want to test
playground-testing-step-4: Click 'Start Session' to begin the conversation
playground-testing-step-5: Speak naturally and observe how your assistant responds
playground-screenshot-caption: Playground interface during an active session
playground-testing-note: Test different scenarios and edge cases. This is the best way to refine your assistant's prompts and tool configurations.
playground-use-cases-intro: The Playground is valuable for several purposes:
playground-use-case-1: Pre-production testing before publishing to customers
playground-use-case-2: Debugging conversation flows and tool integrations
playground-use-case-4: Training team members on how the assistant works
reports-history-intro: The Call History shows all interactions with your voice assistants, providing complete visibility into customer conversations.
reports-history-viewing-content: The Reports page displays a table of all calls with key information: date, assistant, caller, duration, tokens used, and cost.
reports-history-filter-date: Date Range - Select specific time periods
reports-history-filter-caller: Caller - Search by caller ID or phone number
reports-history-details-content: Click any call to view the full conversation transcript and detailed metrics.
reports-history-screenshot-caption: Call history table with filtering options
reports-metrics-intro: Reports provide detailed metrics to help you understand system performance and costs.
reports-metrics-calls-content: Total number of calls, average call duration, and call volume trends over time.
reports-metrics-duration-content: Track average, minimum, and maximum call durations to understand conversation patterns.
reports-metrics-tokens-content: Monitor AI token consumption across calls. Helps predict costs and optimize model selection.
reports-metrics-cost-content: View total and per-call costs. Breakdown by assistant, time period, or customer.
reports-visualizations-intro: Visual charts help you quickly understand trends and patterns:
reports-visualizations-activity: Call Activity - Volume of calls over time
reports-visualizations-duration: Duration Trends - How call length changes over time
reports-export-intro: Export your call data to Excel for further analysis or record-keeping.
reports-export-step-1: Apply any desired filters to the report
reports-export-step-3: Save the generated file, which includes all visible data with your filters applied
payments-balance-intro: The Payment page shows your current credit balance and provides options to manage billing.
payments-balance-current-content: Your credit balance is displayed prominently. All usage is deducted from this balance automatically.
payments-balance-usage-content: You are charged based on actual usage: call duration, AI tokens consumed, and other resources. No monthly fees.
payments-topup-intro: Add funds to your account to ensure uninterrupted service.
payments-topup-step-1: Go to the Payment page and click 'Top Up Balance'
payments-topup-step-2: Enter the amount you want to add (in USD)
payments-topup-step-3: Complete the payment using your preferred method
payments-topup-step-4: Your balance will be updated immediately after payment confirmation
payments-notifications-intro: Set up balance alerts to avoid service interruptions.
payments-notifications-step-1: Navigate to the Payment page and find the 'Notification Threshold' section
payments-notifications-step-2: Enter the balance amount that should trigger an alert (e.g., $10)
payments-notifications-step-3: Add email addresses to receive notifications when your balance reaches this threshold
payments-history-intro: Track all payment transactions in one place.
payments-history-viewing-content: The Payment History tab shows all deposits, charges, and balance changes with dates and amounts.
payments-history-export-content: Click 'Export to Excel' to download your payment history for accounting purposes.
payments-organizations-intro: Manage organization details for invoicing and billing purposes.
payments-organizations-step-1: Click 'Add Organization' on the Organizations tab
payments-organizations-step-2: Enter organization details: name, TIN (tax ID), address
payments-organizations-step-3: Save the organization details for use in invoices
payments-organizations-editing-content: Click the edit icon next to any organization to update its information.
publish-overview-intro: AI PBX provides flexible ways to integrate voice assistants into your business processes and infrastructure.
publish-overview-method-sips: SIP Integration - Connect to your existing IP-telephony or cloud PBX
publish-overview-method-widgets: Web Widgets - Make calls directly from your website via browser
publish-overview-method-pbxs: Custom Servers - Use your Asterisk infrastructure for call processing
publish-sips-intro: SIP integration allows your assistant to receive and make calls through standard VoIP protocols.
publish-sips-step-1: Create a SIP account in Publish -> SIPs
publish-sips-step-2: Select an assistant and PBX server (cloud or private)
publish-sips-step-4: Use the generated SIP URI in your PBX for call routing
publish-sips-note: SIP requires your server to be able to send traffic to the specified PBX server SIP host.
publish-widgets-intro: Voice widgets allow customers to talk to an assistant directly on your site without using a phone.
publish-widgets-step-1: Create a new widget in Publish -> Widgets
publish-widgets-step-3: Specify allowed domains to protect against unauthorized use
publish-widgets-step-4: Copy the integration code and paste it into your site before the </body> tag
publish-pbxs-intro: The PBX section allows managing integration servers that provide the link between AI and telephony.
publish-pbxs-field-wss: WSS URL - Address for connecting WebRTC widgets via WebSocket
publish-pbxs-field-ari: ARI URL - Asterisk REST Interface for call logic management
publish-pbxs-field-context: Context - The dialplan context in Asterisk where incoming calls are processed
asterisk-config-intro: To work with your own Asterisk server, you need to perform basic ARI and PJSIP configuration.
asterisk-config-ari-content:
[general]
enabled = yes
pretty = yes

[user]
read_only = no
password = your_password
password_format = plain
asterisk-config-dialplan-content:
[from-internal]
exten => 100,1,NoOp(AI Assistant Call)
 same => n,Stasis(aipbx)
 same => n,Hangup()
assistants-fields-intro: Each assistant is configured through a form containing several cards. Below is a detailed description of every field and how it affects the assistant's behavior.
assistants-fields-name-desc: The assistant's name for internal identification. Displayed in the assistant list and reports.
assistants-fields-model-desc: The AI language model. Determines response quality, speed, and cost. GPT — deeper dialogues; Qwen — faster and cheaper.
assistants-fields-voice-desc: The voice persona the assistant speaks with. Affects tone, gender, and accent.
assistants-fields-tools-desc: Attach tools (Function Calling / MCP). The assistant will be able to call these functions during dialogue.
assistants-fields-analytics-desc: When enabled, AI analytics are generated after each call: sentiment, summary, topic.
assistants-fields-comment-desc: Internal note. Does not affect the assistant's operation.
assistants-fields-instruction-desc: The system prompt — the main text defining the assistant's behavior, knowledge, and style. See 'Prompting Guide' for details.
assistants-fields-instruction-example: You are a customer support agent for Company X…
assistants-fields-generator-desc: The 'Generate' button opens a window where you can describe a task and AI will create a ready-made prompt for your assistant.
assistants-fields-temperature-desc: Controls response randomness. 0.6 — precise, predictable responses. 1.2 — more creative and varied.
assistants-fields-vad-threshold-desc: Minimum confidence (0.0–1.0) at which the system determines the user has started speaking. Higher threshold — fewer false positives.
assistants-fields-vad-prefix-desc: How many milliseconds of audio before the VAD trigger to include in recognition. Helps not lose the beginning of a phrase.
assistants-fields-vad-silence-desc: How many milliseconds of silence must pass after speech ends for the system to understand the user has finished speaking.
assistants-fields-idle-timeout-desc: Maximum idle time (in seconds) after which the session ends automatically.
assistants-fields-advanced-intro: These settings are only available to system administrators and allow fine-tuning the speech processing pipeline.
assistants-fields-max-tokens-desc: Maximum number of tokens the model can use to generate a single response.
assistants-fields-stt-model-desc: Speech-to-Text engine for converting voice to text.
assistants-fields-stt-lang-desc: Expected language of incoming speech for optimal accuracy.
assistants-fields-tts-model-desc: Text-to-Speech engine for converting response text to voice.
assistants-fields-tts-lang-desc: Language for voicing the assistant's responses.
assistants-fields-noise-desc: Enable background noise filtering to improve recognition.
assistants-fields-vad-type-desc: Voice activity detection algorithm: server_vad (server-side) or semantic_vad (AI-based semantic).
assistants-fields-semantic-eagerness-des: AI 'eagerness' level with semantic VAD. Low — waits longer; High — interrupts faster.
assistants-fields-advanced-warning: Changing advanced settings without understanding their impact may degrade dialogue quality. We recommend keeping default values.
assistants-prompting-intro: The system prompt is the foundation that defines your voice assistant's behavior. A well-crafted prompt is the key to quality dialogues.
assistants-prompting-what-content: A system prompt is a set of instructions that define the role, context, tasks, and constraints of the assistant. The AI model receives this text before each dialogue and builds its behavior based on it. Think of it as a job description for your virtual employee.
assistants-prompting-structure-intro: A good prompt contains 5 key elements:
assistants-prompting-structure-role: Role — who are you? (operator, administrator, consultant, tech support)
assistants-prompting-structure-context: Context — where do you work? (company name, industry, specifics)
assistants-prompting-structure-tasks: Tasks — what should you do? (numbered list of actions in order)
assistants-prompting-structure-constrain: Constraints — what should you NOT do? (clear boundaries of competence)
assistants-prompting-tip-1: Be specific. Instead of 'help customers', write 'help schedule an appointment by collecting date, time, and name'.
assistants-prompting-tip-2: Specify constraints. An assistant without constraints will answer any question, even off-topic ones.
assistants-prompting-tip-3: Number your tasks. This helps the model execute them sequentially.
assistants-prompting-tip-4: Mention functions. If functions are attached, reference them by name in the prompt.
assistants-prompting-tip-5: Test in Playground. Check your prompt across various scenarios and adjust wording.
assistants-prompting-tips-advice: Use the 'Generate' button for quick prompt creation. Describe the task in one sentence, and AI will compose a complete prompt that you can refine.
assistants-prompting-example2-subtitle: Food delivery with address and menu verification
tools-fc-examples-intro: Below are real examples of function configurations (Function Calling) in JSON format. Each example includes the function name, description (used by the model to decide when to call), parameters, and their types.
tools-fc-examples-booking-desc: A function for booking client appointments. The assistant gathers name, phone, date and time, then calls this function. With webhook — data is sent to your API endpoint.
tools-fc-examples-order-desc: A simple function for retrieving order information. The assistant asks for the order number and calls the function to get the status from your system.
tools-fc-examples-ticket-desc: A function for escalating unresolved issues. The assistant creates a ticket with the problem description and priority.
tools-fc-examples-tip: The function description is the most important field. The model decides when to call a function based on it. Write descriptions as detailed and specific as possible.
tools-builtin-intro: AI PBX provides several built-in utility functions available to all assistants when integrated via Asterisk (SIP). These functions don't require webhook creation — they are executed directly by the platform.
tools-builtin-hangup-desc: The assistant calls this function when the dialogue is complete and needs to hang up. Useful for automatically ending the call after all questions are resolved.
tools-builtin-hangup-note: The hangup_call function only works when connected via Asterisk. For WebRTC widget calls, this function does not apply.
tools-builtin-transfer-desc: Allows the assistant to transfer the call to another number or dialplan context. Typically used to transfer to a live operator when the assistant can't resolve the issue.
tools-builtin-transfer-tip: In the assistant's prompt, specify when to transfer calls. For example: 'If the client asks to speak with an operator 3 times, call transfer_call with extension 200'.
tools-builtin-warning: Utility functions only work when integrated via Asterisk (SIP). For WebRTC widgets, call management is handled through the client's browser.
